In both the chlorine dioxide worst case and alternative release scenarios, EPA's WATER8 emission calculation model was used to estimate the chlorine dioxide volatilization and EPA's SLAB dispersion model was used to predict downwind distance to the 1.0-PPM toxic endpoint.  The worst case scenario released 451.4 lbs/min of chlorine dioxide with an 11.8 mile (19 kilometers) radius to the ClO2 toxic endpoint of 1.0 ppmv. Using EPA's LandView III environmental mapping software, an estimated 9,584 homes and 26,722 people are within this area. Lake Lowndes State Park and the Columbus lock & dam recreational area are also located within this radius. 

Ä Chlorine Dioxide - Alternative Release Scenario #1
Scenario #1 assumed that a level transmitter in the chlorine dioxide storage tank failed and that the tank overflowed for 30 minutes before operators noted the overflow. This is unlikely due to gas monitors around the storage tank area and the presence of operators working in Chem Prep. The storage tank overflow is hard piped to the acid sewer and most of the chlorine dioxide gas would be released downstream of the ClO2 generator area off the wastewater treatment system sumps and clarifier. 

With a production rate of 600 gallons per minute, a total of 18,000 gallons would be sewered in this scenario. Using EPA's WATER8 and SLAB models, the chlorine dioxide release rate was modeled a

t 5.2 lbs/minute with an endpoint of 0.47 miles. LandView III software showed there were two homes and 8 people are within this radius. There are no environmental receptors in this area. 

Ä Chlorine Dioxide - Alternative Release Scenario #2
Alternative release scenario #2 assumed that the chlorine dioxide storage tank was 60% full and an I beam or other heavy object was dropped during a maintenance activity around the tank, hitting the pump discharge line at the bottom of the tank shearing it away. Approximately 53,658 gallons of chlorine dioxide solution was released over a 22 minute period through an 8 inch orifice where the discharge line was sheared away from the tank.

Similar to the worst case release scenario, there are generally 4 separate pathways the solution would flow. The containment would fill and drain to the acid sewer (pathway 1) but once the containment was filled, the release would split about evenly with part exiting the north entrance to the chlorine dioxide containment and flowing into a ditch draining to the process sewer (pathway 2). The released solution would also exit the south entrance to the chlorine dioxide containment area and split evenly (pathway 3 and 4) with one portion flowing west into the Chem Prep ally sewer drains and another part flowing east into the stormwater ditch. The chlorine dioxide release rate for the second alternative release scenario was modeled at 94.8 lbs/minute with a 1.0 ppm endpoint radius of 2.0 miles. LandView III showed there are approximately 50 homes and 151 people within a 2 mile radius of the plant. There are no environmental receptors within this radius.
 
Accidental Release Prevention Program
The CPPC accident prevention program for chlorine dioxide complies with OSHA Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119).

Weyerhaeuser Columbus Pulp & Paper Complex
RMP Executive Summary

Weyerhaeuser's Columbus Pulp & Paper Complex is committed to safely operating its facility to protect its employees, the public and the environment.  EPA requires regulated facilities to submit Risk Management Plans describing the risk management program at its facilities. This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management system at Weyerhaeuser's Columbus Pulp & Paper Complex.  

Accidental release and emergency response policy
To protect the environment and the health and safety of our employees and the public, we expect full compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. The facility's emphasis on accident prevention is demonstrated by having one of the lowest Recordable Injury Rates in the industry, being among the first pulp & paper facilities in the United States to achieve OSHA Star status and through emphasis on continuous improvement in it's safety programs. 

The emergency response program has a trained emergency response team with equipment for responding to on-site fires, hazardous material releases, emergency medical response and rescue. The program has a dedicated emergency response coordinator responsible for coordinating the weekly training and development of the emergency response team. Response activities have been discussed with the Lowndes LEPC and county fire departments. The commitment to an injury free' work environment is supported by a safety management system that includes: 
¨ OSHA Star Voluntary Protection Plan certification
¨ Plant Safety and Health Guideline Documentation
¨ Job Safety Analysis
¨ Standard Operating Procedures 
¨ Regular millwide safety audits
¨ Safety Benchmarking
¨ Millwide safety goals
¨ Contractor safety and environmental education
¨ Annual Health Screens
¨ Annual Hearing tests
¨ Safety Performance Recognition
¨ Chemical Purchase Approval Process
¨ Materi

al Safety Data Sheet System	¨ Process Safety Management system

¨ Safety Preventative Maintenance routes

¨ Weekly housekeeping inspections/reports

¨ Monthly safety meetings

The elements of EPA's Risk Management regulations (40 CFR 68) and OSHA Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119) have been integrated into one program to safely manage risks and protect both workers and the community. 

Columbus Pulp & Paper Complex and Regulated Substances
The Columbus Pulp & Paper Complex (CPPC) is located in south Lowndes County, Mississippi. The facility manufactures Lightweight Coated (LWC) fine paper and bleached kraft pulp and employs about 670 employees. The LWC paper is used in printed material such as magazines and newspaper inserts. The bleached kraft pulp operation manufactures papergrade and fluff pulp. The papergrade and fluff pulp is sold and made, respectively, into fine paper and absorbent products such as diapers.

There is one RMP covered chemical used on the plant site. Chlorine dioxide (ClO2) gas is a yellowish/green gas manufactured on the plant site and used to bleach kraft pulp. There are 2 ClO2 solution storage tanks with a volume of 94,000 gallons each. The chlorine dioxide generator is capable of manufacturing about 600 gallons/minute at a concentration of 10.8 grams/liter solution (1.08%). 

Offsite Consequence Analysis
The RMP rule requires Weyerhaeuser to perform an off site consequence analysis for the following scenarios:
· One worst case and one alternative release scenario for the toxic substance chlorine dioxide

The PHA findings are shared with employees working with hazardous chemicals. Employees are advised of any necessary changes brought about by the PHA and, in some cases, may be involved in the design change and implementation process. 

Ä Operating Procedures: 
CPPC process engineers, operators, and management work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safety performed. Employees participate in operating procedure development in several ways: 
1. Employees are consulted during procedure development and implementation to determine if the procedures accurately reflect what is practiced in the field and what additional measures should be added to increase worker safety and protect the environment.
2. Development of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) are assigned to employees that have recognized knowledge, experience and job skills related to the assigned procedure. 
3. Implementation of new processes or procedures is assigned to a commissioning team. These assignments typically include an opportunity for a critique of the work processes and procedures. 

Ä Training: 
CPPC trains employees to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. Employees are trained through self-taught learning materials including operations manuals, educational modules and computer based education programs. In addition, employees are trained one-on-one through on-the-job training in the field. Employees are encouraged to identify education needs and take part in education development and implementation. Skills are demonstrated through written exams, oral exams, and through proficiency demonstrations.

Ä Mechanical Integrity 
CPPC maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment fail

ures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. Employees record equipment history, data and observations, maintain the MMS database, and generate Reliability Maintenance system reports. The employee doing the actual test and inspection work is typically asked to review and comment about manufacturers recommendations for preventive maintenance procedures and test frequencies. Employees take part in equipment failure reviews, participate in work process critiques, and are encouraged to make recommendations for change. 

Ä Management of change: 
The CPPC management of change program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind are approved without completing the full management of change process. All other changes must be approved through the management of change process to ensure that potential accidents resulting from change are prevented, safety concerns of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.  

Ä Pre-startup Review: 
CPPC performs a safety review of a new or modified process before the process is placed into service to ensure that the process has been prepared to operate safely. Team members with appropriate knowledge and skills are employed in the pre-startup review process at CPPC. Team members are encouraged to ask safety questions, do individual prestartup safety reviews, and discuss any concerns identified. 

Ä Compliance Audits: 
CPPC conducts periodic environmental and safety audits against the provisions of the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP Rules, internal procedures and standards. Team members will be interviewed as part of audit protocols to permit them to give input on the specific issues being audited. Audit reports, response plans and status upd

ates will be shared with affected employees. 

Ä Incident Investigation: 
CPPC investigates all incidents that could have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented. Team members are involved in incident investigation since their knowledge and skills in operations or maintenance are necessary to conduct the investigation. Once investigation team reports become available, the results and recommendations of the team are made available to those working in the process or operation. Communication is in the form of a report, which is circulated among employees and is discussed in scheduled safety meetings and in ad hoc meetings with team members. 

Ä Employee Participation : 
CPPC developed a written employee participation program for covered processes to help ensure that the safety concerns of CPPC workers are addressed. Team members participate in compiling process safety and maintenance information with field checks to verify the accuracy of P&IDs, loop sketches, and equipment drawings used in normal work processes and through communication of observations made during the normal conduct of their work - particularly those that reflect operational safety hazards. 

Ä Hot Work Permits (Safe Work Practices): 
CPPC established a hot work permit program to control activities which may result in fires or explosions in covered processes. Team members, with appropriate job skills and experience, participate in the review of safe work practice procedures through their involvement with safety subteams, site-central safety core team or ad-hoc task teams.  A cross section of knowledgeable team members may be called upon to draft procedures and revisions to procedures. During the development or changes to critical activity procedures, emphasis is placed on involving a core functional team that will be affected by the procedure. 

Ä Contractors: 
CPPC established a program to ensure that contractor activities a

t the CPPC facility are performed in a safe manner. Team members at CPPC have an integral role in the interface with contractors working at the site. They often work side-by-side with contract employees and have a high level of knowledge about how the contractor's work can affect or be affected by the process or adjacent processes. Each site team member and contract employee is encouraged to ash questions and to raise concerns about unsafe work activities or conditions. Site team members are expected to inform contract employers of the potential hazards of fire, explosion or toxic releases when repairing equipment so that contractors can work on it safely.

Ä Emergency Planning and Response: 
CPPC has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. A formal review process to solicit and obtain employees input on millwide procedures exists to improve site emergency response plans. Employees and participants in both safety incidents and drills conduct critiques to get comments and observations, identify learnings, identify opportunities for performance improvement and improve both emergency response planning and responder performance. Communication to both team members and contractors takes place on both formal and informal levels to that there is a complete understanding of the actions one should take in an emergency situation. 

Ä Trade Secrets: 
Numerous examples are given in the preceding 12 sections of the Employee Participation Plan where team members have access to information developed to meet the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management Rule. It is the intent of site management to disclose to team members and contract employees as necessary (subject to 29 CFR 1910.1200(i) trade secret protection constraints where applicable) the process safety related information needed to have an informed workforce whose efforts and attention to detail will ensure the CPPC continues to be a saf

e workplace. 

5 Year Accident History
One chlorine dioxide injury occurred within the past 5 years. On November 26, 1996, an employee opened a valve spilling some pulp stock from the bleaching process. A conservative estimate of 25 - 30 lbs of chlorine dioxide gas was released from the stock irritating the employee. The employee saw the plant nurse and was taken to the emergency room for overnight observation. There were no other onsite or offsite impacts and offsite responders were not notified.

An incident investigation task team met and began a 12 point process investigation. The 12 point process investigation was completed and corrective actions were implemented. Job Safety Analysis were updated and more sensitive ClO2 gas monitors were purchased and installed. No ClO2 equipment design or installation deficiencies were found. 

Emergency Response Program
An Emergency Response Team capable of providing multiple emergency response functions is available on the plantsite. The team has regular Haz-Mat, fire fighting, and confined space/high angle rescue training and drills. In addition, the team is trained in CPR, patient packaging and handling and bloodborne pathogens. 

In emergencies, the shift manager is the incident commander who determines the degree of hazard and risk posed to public health and the environment. An internal alert alarm system can be sounded to summon the emergency response team. Procedures for regulatory, emergency management agency, and public notification are documented in the Quality System. Mutual aid requests are made through 911 notification. 

Continuous Improvement
Continuous improvement in our safety and environmental programs is the expectation at CPPC. Near miss and safety incident investigations, root cause analysis and corrective action implementation support continuous improvement. In addition, Plant Safety and Health Guidelines are being updated and moved to the Quality System for ease of use and updating. Individual safety pl
ans are being developed for each employee on the plant site defining their role and commitment to safe work practices. These improvements are to support continuous improvement in safe work practices.
